## How to get a domain

:::: {.columns}

::: {.column width="50%"}

### Overview

- **Buy**. Actually, rent from DNS provider.
- **Register**. Typically, with [ICANN](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ICANN) via DNS provider.

:::

::: {.column width="50%"}

### Detailed steps

- Go to a DNS provider (e.g., Namecheap, Godaddy, AWS Route 53, etc)
- Search for a domain name in a top-level domain (e.g. `hello-world` in `.com`)
- Pay to use it
- Provide some personal details for registration (that DNS providers typically redacts)

:::

::::


## How to link your server and your domain

:::: {.columns}

::: {.column width="60%"}

### Networking table ...

| Path/Host | Type | Target |
| --------- | ---- | ------ |
| `@` | `A` | 64.56.223.5 |
| www | `CNAME` | example.com |
| blog | `A` | 114.13.56.77 |
| * | `A` | 64.56.223.5 |

:::

::: {.column width="40%"}

### ... explained

::: {.fragment .incremental}
- `@`. Traffic to exactly `example.com` -> IP `64...`
- `www`.  Traffic to `www.example.com` -> `example.com` -> IP `64...`
- `blog`. `blog.example.com` -> different IP
- `*`. Everything else -> IP `64....`
:::

:::

::::
